questions.text: Pencil shaped macroconidia are seen in? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichophyton

 

Explanation:

 

Pencil-shaped macroconidia are a distinguishing feature of the fungus Trichophyton. Trichophyton is one of the three genera of dermatophytes, which also include Microsporum and Epidermophyton.

 

Dermatophytes cause infections known as dermatophytosis or ringworm, which affect keratinized tissues such as the skin, hair, and nails.

 

Dermatophytosis can be classified into three species:

 

  1. Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped).  In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes.
  2. Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent.
  3. Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Microsporum: The macroconidia of Microsporum are spindle-shaped and spiny, not pencil-shaped. This genus primarily affects skin and hair.

 

Option C. Epidermophyton: The macroconidia of Epidermophyton are club-shaped, not pencil-shaped. This genus affects skin and nails.

 

Option D. Clostridium: This is a genus of bacteria, not fungi, and it does not produce macroconidia. Clostridium species are known for producing spores, not conidia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pencil-shaped macroconidia are characteristic of Trichophyton, a genus of dermatophytes that affects skin, hair, and nails.

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

choices.text: No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

 

No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination: The resident's serology shows that HBsAg is negative and Anti-HBs is greater than 105 mIU/ml, which indicates that he has sufficient immunity against Hepatitis B from prior vaccination. No further treatment is necessary because the antibody titres are already protective.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Booster dose of vaccine: Not required since the resident already has sufficient antibody levels indicating immunity.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin with full vaccination: This would be necessary if the resident had low or no detectable antibody titres, indicating no prior immunity.

 

Option C. Repeat full course of vaccine: Not necessary because the resident already has adequate antibody titres indicating immunity.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure seen in this skin biopsy from a patient with persistent subcutaneous nodules along the lymphatics: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Asteroid body

 

Explanation:

 

The asteroid body is a diagnostic hallmark of Sporothrix schenckii infection. It appears as a central fungal spore surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material, forming a star-shaped structure due to the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon. This is characteristic of sporotrichosis, which typically presents as subcutaneous nodules spreading along lymphatic channels.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Copper pennies – These are sclerotic bodies (medlar bodies), which are thick-walled, brown, septate fungal structures resembling coins. They are pathognomonic for chromoblastomycosis, not sporotrichosis.
  • Option C: Figure of 8 appearance –Under the microscope, the budding yeast of Blastomyces sometimes resembles a "figure 8" due to its broad attachment between the mother and daughter cell during replication.
  • Option D: Pilot wheel – The "pilot wheel" or "captain's wheel" structure is associated with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. The fungal yeast form has a large, central mother cell with multiple buds symmetrically arranged around it, resembling the spokes of a ship’s wheel. This is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The asteroid body is a pathognomonic structure for Sporothrix schenckii infection, especially in lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis, presenting as subcutaneous nodules along the lymphatic channels.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

choices.text: Albendazole is the drug of choice
Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans
Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

 

The given image shows hymenolepis nana egg. Egg is spherical or ovoid and has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar. Filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

Hymenolepis nana is the smallest and the most common tapeworm found in the human intestine.

 

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children. There are usually no symptoms but in heavy infections, there is nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

 

Praziquantel (single dose of 25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice, since it acts both against the adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide 500 mg BD for 3 days may be used as alternative.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Albendazole is the drug of choice: This is incorrect. The drug of choice for Hymenolepis nana is praziquantel (a single dose of 25 mg/kg) because it acts against both adult worms and the cysticercoids in the intestinal villi. Nitazoxanide (500 mg BD for 3 days) may be used as an alternative.

 

Option C. Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants: This is incorrect. The infection with Hymenolepis nana is not acquired through aquatic plants. Infections are usually acquired by ingestion of contaminated food or water or by autoinfection.

 

Option D. Non-segmented leaf-like parasite: This is incorrect. Hymenolepis nana is a segmented tapeworm, not a non-segmented leaf-like parasite.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the most common and smallest tapeworm in humans. Majority of infections are asymptomatic. The drug of choice is praziquantel.

 

Parasites with aquatic plants as the source of infection:

 

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Watsonius watsoni
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

 

Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

 

Points in favor:

 

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts are smaller (8-12 µm) and round, with variable acid-fast staining. They sporulate in soil and contain two sporocysts with two sporozoites each.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium oocysts are even smaller (4-6 µm) and round. They are uniformly acid-fast and contain four sporozoites. Sporulation occurs inside the host cell.

 

Option D. Microspora: Microspora are obligate intracellular parasites that do not have the same oocyst structure as coccidian parasites. They are detected by different staining methods and appear as small spores rather than larger oocysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a-3, b-1, c-4, d-2

 

A-3. Rotavirus is a member of the Reoviridae family, which is an exception among RNA viruses because it has double-stranded RNA (dsRNA).

 

B-1. SARS-CoV-2 is a coronavirus, which is a single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) virus.

 

C-4. Parvovirus is a unique DNA virus because it has single-stranded DNA (ssDNA).

 

D-2. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) belongs to the Papillomaviridae family and has double-stranded DNA (dsDNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the nucleic acid composition of viruses is crucial. Rotavirus has dsRNA, SARS-CoV-2 has ssRNA, Parvovirus has ssDNA, and HPV has dsDNA.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: The test shown in the image below. Which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

 

The given image shows blood agar culture with bacitracin disk with a zone of inhibition around the disk, which means that the organism is sensitive to bacitracin.

 

Among the options given, Streptococcus pyogenes is susceptible to bacitracin.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is catalase-positive and does not typically exhibit bacitracin sensitivity. It is identified by coagulase testing and its ability to grow in the presence of high salt concentrations.

 

Option C. Clostridium botulinum: Clostridium botulinum is an anaerobic Gram-positive rod and is not identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Option D. Bacillus: Bacillus species are Gram-positive rods that form spores and are not typically identified using bacitracin sensitivity testing.

 

Educational Objective

 

The bacitracin disk test is used to identify Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by its sensitivity to bacitracin and beta-hemolytic activity on blood agar. This test differentiates S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, which are resistant to bacitracin.

questions.text: The causative agent for St. Anthony's Fire is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus

 

Explanation:

 

St. Anthony’s Fire, also known as erysipelas, is primarily caused by Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes). Erysipelas is an acute infection affecting the superficial layers of the skin, particularly the dermis, and is characterized by a sharply defined, bright red, and swollen area of skin. The infection also involves prominent lymphatic involvement. The term "St. Anthony's Fire" dates back to the Middle Ages, when it was mistakenly thought to be caused by the ingestion of ergot-contaminated rye.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus species, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, are common causes of various skin infections, but they are not typically associated with erysipelas.

 

Option C. Klebsiella: Klebsiella species are gram-negative bacteria that can cause a range of infections, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections, but they are not linked to erysipelas.

 

Option D. Nocardia: Nocardia species are bacteria that can cause nocardiosis, a serious infection that can affect the lungs, brain, and skin, but they are not responsible for erysipelas.

 

Educational objective:

 

Erysipelas, also known as St. Anthony's Fire, is caused by Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

 

It is a chronic deep cutaneous fungal infection usually affecting the limbs at the inoculation site

 

Causative agents include several fungi found in soil, wood and decaying plant material:

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosi (most common pathogen, accounts for > 90% of the cases in South America)
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Cladosporium carrionii
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa (Ramichloridium cerophilum)

 

Common clinical presentation is verrucous lesion over extremities of adult men engaged in outdoor work. Lesion starts as a small firm red / gray bump on the traumatized skin on the foot or hand. Grows slowly (2 mm/year) to form raised hyperkeratotic (crusted, warty-looking) plaque

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It typically presents with flu-like symptoms, skin lesions, and sometimes lung involvement. The histopathology would show broad-based budding yeast rather than medlar bodies.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: This refers to a group of fungal infections caused by dematiaceous (dark-walled) fungi. The infection can present in various forms, from superficial to deep infections, but it does not typically produce medlar bodies.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Caused by Sporothrix schenckii, this infection usually follows a thorn prick and presents as nodular lesions that can ulcerate. The characteristic histopathological finding is cigar-shaped yeast, not medlar bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury, with histopathological evidence of medlar bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a Category B bioterrorism agent? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: A) Coxiella burnetti

 

Explanation: 

 

Coxiella burnetti, the causative agent of Q fever, is classified as a Category B bioterrorism agent by the CDC. Category B agents are moderately easy to disseminate, cause moderate morbidity and low mortality, and require enhanced disease surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Variola virus: This is a Category A agent that causes smallpox. It has high potential for mass casualties and requires special public health preparedness.

 

Option C) Ebola virus: This is a Category A agent due to its high mortality rate, potential for public panic, and requirement for special public health preparedness.

 

Option D) Bacillus anthracis: This is a Category A agent due to its ease of dissemination, high mortality rate (especially in inhalational form), and potential for causing public panic.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the CDC's classification of bioterrorism agents:

  • Category A: Highest priority (easily disseminated, high mortality)
  • Category B: Moderate priority (moderately easy to disseminate, moderate morbidity, low mortality)
  • Category C: Emerging threats (potential for future weaponization)

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organisms shown below acts via? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ADP ribosylation of EF2

 

The given image shows gram-positive rods with club-shaped ends, beaded appearance, and a Chinese-letter pattern of arrangement indicative of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

 

Diphtheria toxin functions by selectively ADP-ribosylating ribosomal elongation factor, EF-2, attenuating protein synthesis and leading to cell death within a matter of hours. DT is a highly potent toxin. It is bacteriophage mediated.

 

NOTE: Pseudomonas toxin also inhibits protein synthesis by ADP ribosylation of EF2.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Increase in cAMP: This mechanism is typically associated with toxins such as cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which lead to an increase in intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP) by ADP-ribosylating G proteins, but not involved in the action of diphtheria toxin.

 

Option B. Increase in cGMP: This mechanism is not relevant to diphtheria toxin but is associated with certain bacterial toxins like heat-stable enterotoxin (ST) produced by E. coli, which increases cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels.

 

Option D. RNA glycosidase: This mechanism refers to Shiga toxin and ricin, which inhibit protein synthesis by enzymatically removing adenine from rRNA, but it is not the mode of action for diphtheria toxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diphtheria toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), thereby inhibiting protein synthesis and leading to cell death.

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

 

Explanation:

 

The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.

 

While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.

 

Pernicious malaria -  (due to heavy parasitization)

 

  • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs

 

Other Options:

 

A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown in the image? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Darkfield microscopy

 

The given image is of darkfield microscopy as it has a dark background with a refractile organism.

 

Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive technique to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present. This technique allows for a presumptive diagnosis of syphilis even before antibodies have developed.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Phase contrast microscopy:

 

  • Phase contrast microscopy enhances the contrast of transparent specimens without staining. It is often used for live cells and other transparent samples.
  • The background in phase contrast microscopy is not typically as dark as in darkfield microscopy.

 

Option C. Fluorescent microscopy

 

  • Fluorescent microscopy uses fluorophores to stain specific structures, which then emit light when exposed to specific wavelengths. The images typically show bright fluorescent colors against a dark background.

 

Option D. Electron microscopy

 

  • Electron microscopy uses a beam of electrons to create an image. The images produced are typically in black and white with extremely high resolution, showing detailed structures at the nanoscale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Darkfield microscopy is identified by its characteristic bright specimen against a dark background and is commonly used for diagnosing syphilis through visualization of spirochetes.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cell

 

Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

 

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

 

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. B cell: Incorrect because the primary immunodeficiency in nude mice relates to T cells, not B cells. While B cells are essential for antibody production, their presence does not compensate for the lack of T cell-mediated immunity necessary for xenograft rejection.

 

Option C. Both B and T cell: Incorrect as nude mice specifically lack T cells due to the absence of a thymus, while B cell function remains intact.

 

Option D. INK cell: Incorrect because the term should likely refer to "NK cells" (natural killer cells), which are not the primary reason for the lack of xenograft rejection in nude mice. NK cells can participate in innate immune responses but do not compensate for the lack of adaptive immune responses mediated by T cells in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


Nude mice lack a thymus, resulting in a deficiency of mature T cells, which are essential for rejecting xenografts. This highlights the crucial role of T cells in adaptive immune responses and graft rejection.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1

 

9-valent HPV vaccine (Gardasil-9) is a non-infectious recombinant vaccine prepared from the purified virus-like particles (VLPs) of the major capsid (L1) protein of HPV types 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

 

Available HPV vaccines protect against either two, four, or nine types of HPV. All HPV vaccines protect against at least HPV types 16 and 18, which cause the greatest risk of cervical cancer. It is estimated that HPV vaccines may prevent 70% of cervical cancer, 80% of anal cancer, 60% of vaginal cancer, 40% of vulvar cancer, and show more than 90% efficacy in preventing HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers. They additionally prevent some genital warts, with the quadrivalent and nonavalent vaccines that protect against HPV types HPV-6 and HPV-11 providing greater protection.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. E6, E7: These proteins are oncogenes that contribute to the development of cancer by interfering with tumor suppressor proteins such as p53 and Rb but are not components of the vaccine.

 

Option C. E1, E2: These are early proteins involved in the replication and regulation of HPV DNA but are not used in the vaccine formulation.

 

Option D. L2: This is a minor capsid protein of HPV, but the vaccine primarily uses the major capsid protein L1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MTB + Rifampicin resistance

 

Explanation:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.

 

The key points are:

 

  1. CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection  limit  à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  2. In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  3. CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.

 

Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.

 

Additional Information –

 

Laboratory Diagnosis

 

  1. Direct microscopy by acid-fast staining
  2. Kinyoun’s Cold acid-fast Staining
  3. Fluorescence Staining
  4. Culture Methods
    1. Conventional Media
    2. Automated Liquid Culture  à BACTEC MGIT
  5. Molecular Methods

  6. Polymerase Chain reaction (PCR)

  7. Automated real Time PCR  à  CBNAAT, TrueNat

 

RNTCP diagnostic algorithm -

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Botulinum

 

The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

 

Clostridium botulinum is non-invasive. Its pathogenesis is due to the production of powerful neurotoxin ‘botulinum toxin’ (BoNT). It produces flaccid paralysis. There are 7 serological types of botulinum neurotoxin labeled as types A, B, C [C1 C2], D, E, F, and G. Human botulism is caused mainly by types A, B, E and F (rarely).

 

After entry (either ingested, inhaled, or produced in a wound), botulinum toxin is transported via the blood to peripheral cholinergic nerve terminals. The most common nerve terminal sites are neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia. It does not affect the CNS.

 

Botulinum toxin causes proteolysis of snare proteins that are required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles, thereby preventing the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the peripheral nerve endings, including neuromuscular junctions (presynaptic inhibition). This results in a lack of stimulus to the muscle fibers, irreversible relaxation of the muscles to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal, and flaccid paralysis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Tetanus: Tetanus toxin (produced by Clostridium tetani) acts by inhibiting neurotransmitter release in the central nervous system by cleaving synaptobrevin, another SNARE protein, but it causes spastic paralysis rather than flaccid paralysis.

 

Option C. Diphtheria: Diphtheria toxin (produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae) inhibits protein synthesis in host cells by ADP-ribosylation of elongation factor-2 (EF-2), which is a completely different mechanism from that of botulinum toxin.

 

Option D. Pertussis: Pertussis toxin (produced by Bordetella pertussis) modifies the signaling of G-protein coupled receptors by ADP-ribosylating the Gi protein, thereby affecting cellular communication but not directly impacting acetylcholine release at neuromuscular junctions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at peripheral nerve endings through the proteolysis of SNARE proteins necessary for acetylcholine vesicle exocytosis.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

1 represents the lipopolysaccharide component which is responsible for endotoxic shock in a gram-negative cell wall.

 

 

Conventional gram-negative (LPS-diderm) bacteria display these characteristics:

 

  • An inner cell membrane is present (cytoplasmic)
  • A thin peptidoglycan layer is present (this is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria)
  • Has outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS, which consists of lipid A, core polysaccharide, and O antigen) in its outer leaflet and phospholipids in the inner leaflet
  • Porins exist in the outer membrane, which act like pores for particular molecules
  • Between the outer membrane and the cytoplasmic membrane there is a space filled with a concentrated gel-like substance called periplasm
  • The S-layer is directly attached to the outer membrane rather than to the peptidoglycan
  • If present, flagella have four supporting rings instead of two
  • Teichoic acids or lipoteichoic acids are absent
  • Lipoproteins are attached to the polysaccharide backbone
  • Some contain Braun's lipoprotein, which serves as a link between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan chain by a covalent bond

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: Incorrect: Number 2 represents the flagella, which are responsible for bacterial motility, not endotoxic shock.

 

Option B. 4: Incorrect: Number 4 represents the cytoplasmic membrane, which is not involved in causing endotoxic shock.

 

Option D. 3: Incorrect: Number 3 represents the peptidoglycan layer, which provides structural support to the bacterial cell wall but does not contribute to endotoxic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

questions.text: Farmer with traumatic ulcer in eye and septate hyphae seen. Causative organism is ? (FMGE July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus

 

Explanation:

 

Farmers often suffer from injuries involving organic matter. The presence of a traumatic ulcer in the eye coupled with the identification of septate hyphae points toward a fungal infection.

 

Between Mucor and Aspergillus, the distinguishing factor is the type of hyphae. Aspergillus forms septate hyphae, meaning the hyphae have regular, cross-wall divisions. In contrast, Mucor forms aseptate (or coenocytic) hyphae, which lack these septa.

 

 

Characteristic of Hyphae -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor: Although Mucor is a fungus that can cause infections, it forms aseptate hyphae. This characteristic helps differentiate it from Aspergillus in cases of fungal eye infections.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pyogenes: This bacterium can cause various infections, including those in the eye, but it does not form hyphae. Thus, it cannot be the causative organism in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas: This is another bacterium that can cause eye infections, particularly in the context of contact lens wearers, but like Streptococcus pyogenes, it does not form hyphae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of septate hyphae in an eye infection suggests Aspergillus as the causative organism.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Coxsackievirus

 

The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

 

Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents.

 

Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus:

 

  • Aseptic meningitis associated with a maculopapular rash.
  • Herpangina
  • Minor respiratory infections

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Human herpes virus 7: Associated with roseola infantum, not HFMD.

 

Option C. Pox virus: Causes diseases like smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, characterized by different types of lesions.

 

Option D. Molluscum contagiosum: Causes dome-shaped, pearly lesions with central umbilication, distinct from HFMD vesicles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Coxsackievirus is the causative agent of hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa.

 

Palms and Soles rash is seen in – CARS

 

  1. Coxsackievirus A16
  2. Rocky mountain spotted fever
  3. Secondary Syphilis

questions.text: The culture from a pustular lesion showed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. A provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma can be made by:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bacitracin sensitivity

 

Explanation:

 

Group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are beta-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci. They can be differentiated from other hemolytic streptococci, such as Group B streptococci (S. agalactiae), using the bacitracin sensitivity test. S. pyogenes is sensitive to bacitracin, which inhibits its growth, making this test a key diagnostic tool. When bacitracin is applied to a culture, S. pyogenes shows a zone of inhibition around the bacitracin disk, confirming its identity.

 

Differentiation Tests:

 

  • Catalase test: Differentiates Streptococci from Staphylococci.
  • Bacitracin test: Differentiates Group A Streptococci from other Beta-hemolytic Streptococci.
  • Optochin test: Differentiates Pneumococci from other Alpha-hemolytic Streptococci.
  • Coagulase test: Differentiates Staphylococcus aureus from other Staphylococci.

 

Approach to patient showing Gram-positive cocci:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Catalase positivity: This test differentiates streptococci (catalase-negative) from staphylococci (catalase-positive). Since the bacteria in question are streptococci, catalase positivity is not applicable.

 

Option B. Optochin sensitivity: This test is used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae (optochin-sensitive) from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. It does not apply to beta-hemolytic streptococci like S. pyogenes.

 

Option C. Bile solubility: This test also differentiates S. pneumoniae (bile-soluble) from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. It is not relevant for identifying beta-hemolytic streptococci.

Educational objective:

 

Group A streptococci (S. pyogenes) can be provisionally diagnosed using the bacitracin sensitivity test, which is a differentiating factor from other beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Plasmodium falciparum is identified in the peripheral smear by the presence of multiple rings within a single red blood cell (RBC) and the characteristic headphone-like structure known as the accolé form or appliqué form. In the provided image, multiple rings are visible in some RBCs, and a distinctive headphone-like structure can be observed, which are hallmarks of Plasmodium falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium vivax: This species typically shows a single ring per RBC and can form larger, amoeboid shapes in the late trophozoite stage, which are not seen in this image.

 

Option C. Plasmodium ovale: This species also shows a single ring per RBC and is often characterized by an oval shape of the infected RBC and ragged cell edges, none of which are visible in the provided image.

 

Option D. Plasmodium malariae: This species shows a band form of the trophozoite across the RBC, which is not present in the image. It also typically has fewer merozoites in the schizont stage compared to Plasmodium falciparum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmodium falciparum can be distinguished by the presence of multiple rings in a single RBC and the characteristic headphone-like accolé form.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 17D

 

The above clinical vignette is suggestive of yellow fever and the use of 17D vaccine could have prevented this.

 

17D vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine administered through the subcutaneous route. It is contraindicated in infants less than 9 months of age, in pregnancy, and in individuals with egg allergy.

 

Yellow fever is caused by flavivirus and is endemic to certain parts of Africa and America. It occurs in two patterns: the urban cycle and the sylvatic cycle. Aedes aegypti is the vector in the urban cycle, while Aedes africanus is responsible for transmission in the sylvatic cycle.

 

Patients present with acute onset fever, headache, and vomiting. Jaundice and hemorrhagic manifestations can also be present. Ultimately, hepatic or renal failure can result in death.

 

Torres bodies are intranuclear eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes. These are rarely seen in yellow fever. To prevent the establishment of the disease in India, strict vaccination and quarantine protocols for travelers from endemic areas are enforced.

 

Other options:

 

Option B: Nakayama vaccine is used for immunization against Japanese encephalitis. Culex tritaeniorhynchus is the principal vector. There is a sudden onset of fever and vomiting, which later progresses to encephalitis. In India, it was first reported in Vellore and continues to be active in the country.

 

Option C. Weigl's vaccine is the earliest used vaccine against epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii. The main foci of the disease are Europe, Africa, South America, and Asia. Kashmir is the endemic spot in India. Pediculus humans corporis (human body louse) is the vector. Symptoms include fever and chills. A characteristic rash on the trunk and limbs, sparing the face, palms, and soles, may also be seen.

 

Option D. Jeryl-Lynn strain of the mumps virus is used against the disease as a live-attenuated vaccine. It is contraindicated in pregnancy and individuals allergic to eggs. Mumps present as parotid swelling associated with fever and tenderness.

 

Educational Objective

 

The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Occludens

 

Explanation:

 

Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Integrin: Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option B. Cadherin: Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

choices.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA
Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

 

Southern Blotting: This technique is used for the detection of specific DNA sequences in DNA samples. This is not applicable for detecting SARS-CoV-2 because the virus is RNA-based and there is not enough DNA in the collected samples to obtain a pattern on gel electrophoresis. RNA viruses require different techniques such as RT-PCR for detection.

 

Other Options

 

Tests for SARS CoV2

 

  • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR):

  • Method: This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.

  • Explanation: It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.

  • Rapid Antigen Test:

  • Method: This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.

  • Explanation: It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.

  • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay):

  • Method: This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.

  • Explanation: It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.

 

Educational Objective

 

Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Leptospirosis is the Ans.  because the patient's presentation of symptoms, particularly conjunctival suffusion (redness of the conjunctiva), is more characteristic of Leptospirosis than the other conditions listed. This condition is caused by the Leptospira bacteria, which can lead to symptoms like retro-orbital pain, night fevers, chills, calf tenderness, and hypokalemia, all seen in this patient.

 

The key differentiator in this case is conjunctival suffusion, which is commonly observed in Leptospirosis and is not a typical feature of Dengue or other listed conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Malaria usually presents with high fevers, chills, sweats, and headache but does not typically cause conjunctival suffusion or calf tenderness. Additionally, hypokalemia is not a common feature of Malaria.

 

Option C. Filariasis: Filariasis is characterized by lymphatic dysfunction and can cause lymphedema or elephantiasis, but it does not present with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, or the other acute symptoms described in the patient.

 

Option D. Dengue: Dengue can present with similar symptoms such as retro-orbital pain, fever, and joint pain, making it a close differential. However, conjunctival suffusion is not a characteristic feature of Dengue, which helps to distinguish it from Leptospirosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival suffusion is a distinguishing symptom of Leptospirosis and is not commonly seen in Dengue or other similar infectious conditions.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Legionella

 

BCYE medium (buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella pneumophila. Legionella pneumophila has fastidious growth requirements and grows on complex media such as BCYE medium with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements (e.g, polymyxin B, cefazolin, vancomycin). The charcoal acts as a detoxifying agent. It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Leptospira is cultured on EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson and Harris) medium

 

Option B: Bacillus cereus is cultured on PEMBA (Polymyxin pyruvate egg-yolk mannitol-bromothymol blue) agar, which includes Polymyxin, pyruvate, egg yolk, mannitol, and bromothymol blue to differentiate it from other organisms.

 

Option C: Campylobacter is cultured on selective media such as Skirrow's, Campy BAP or Butzler's agar.

 

Educational Objective

 

BCYE medium is essential for the successful isolation and culture of Legionella species, particularly Legionella pneumophila, from environmental and clinical specimens. This medium meets the specific nutritional requirements and provides a protective environment for the growth of this pathogen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

 

The most likely diagnosis of the given clinical scenario is oral candidiasis.

 

  • Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.
  • The commonly implemented methods for identifying Candida are 10% potassium hydroxide stain and culture with sabouraud dextrose agar. Differentiation of specific species is possible with special culture mediums like CHROMagar Candida. 
  • ELISA and PCR tests are used in cases of invasive candidiasis and to differentiate Candida dubliniensis from Candida albicans.
  • It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.
  • It is treated with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole or fluconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by Epstein Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

 

Option C. Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

 

Option D. Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudo membrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been admitted with symptoms of altered sensorium and hydrophobia, indicating a potential case of rabies, you have obtained corneal scrapings for further investigation. Now, which test would you select to establish a conclusive diagnosis of the condition? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Viral Culture

 

Altered sensorium and hydrophobia is suggestive of rabies which can be diagnosed by viral culture from corneal scrapings.

 

 

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually, Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

 

Virus isolation through culture: best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears and centrifuged urine can also be used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

 

Option B: Seller stain for negri bodies can only be demonstrated in brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon's horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

 

Option D: Real time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect virus in fresh saliva samples, skin, CS, and brain tissues. However, it is not confirmatory test.

 

Educational Objective

 

Viral culture from corneal scrapings is the most definitive test for diagnosing rabies in a patient presenting with altered sensorium and hydrophobia.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus

 

ParvoVirus-B19 infects erythroid progenitor cells and inhibits erythropoiesis, leading to acute erythroblastopenia and reticulocytopenia. The bone marrow in patients with transient aplastic crisis is characterized by an absence of maturing erythroid precursors and presence of giant pro-normoblasts. Although giant pro-normoblasts are suggestive of parvovirus B19 infection, they are not diagnostic of the disease. Aplastic crisis in a patient with hereditary spherocytosis is because of pancytopenia accompanied with a marked decrease in reticulocytes. Bone marrow aspiration may not be routinely required when viral infection-induced aplastic crisis is highly suspected.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Poxvirus: Poxviruses are not associated with causing aplastic crisis.

 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus: While Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) can cause hematologic abnormalities, it is not typically associated with causing aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Adenovirus: Adenovirus infections are common but are not known to cause aplastic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent for aplastic crisis in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. It infects erythroid progenitor cells, inhibiting erythropoiesis and leading to a significant decrease in reticulocytes, causing acute erythroblastopenia.

choices.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India
Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax

 

  • The absence, not the presence, of the Duffy blood group antigen, is protective against P. vivax because the Duffy antigen normally serves as the receptor for Plasmodium vivax.
  • Drug Efflux pumps are the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine. It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1).
  • Algid malaria is a rare complication of severe malaria characterized by hemodynamic collapse manifesting as shock with pronounced metabolic changes and hypothermia.
  • Relapse is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale.
  • Malaria relapse:
    • True relapse is caused due to Hypnozoites.
    • These are resting forms.
  • In the case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which:
    • multiply inside hepatic cells to form - Schizonts
    • others persist and remain dormant as - hypnozoites
  • From time to time some are activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In the case of Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence technically relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India: This statement is correct. Drug-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum are a significant concern in India.

 

Option C. Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: This statement is correct. Algid malaria is a rare but severe complication of malaria characterized by shock and metabolic disturbances.

 

Option D. Relapse is seen in P. ovale: This statement is correct. Relapse is seen in Plasmodium ovale as well as Plasmodium vivax due to the presence of hypnozoites.

 

Educational Objective

 

The absence of the Duffy blood group antigen is protective against Plasmodium vivax, not its presence.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

 

Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

 

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

 

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome.

 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Culex: This genus of mosquitoes is not a known vector for Zika virus but is commonly associated with the transmission of the West Nile virus.

 

Option C. Anopheles: Known primarily for transmitting malaria, not Zika virus.

 

Option D. Phlebotomus papatasii: These are sandflies and known vectors for the virus causing leishmaniasis, not Zika.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris and is found at the top of the tube after centrifugation.

 

Option B. B: This level contains the plug of debris, which is a layer of waste material that is separated from the parasitic elements and sits below the ether layer.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements. The formalin layer sits above the sediment but below the plug of debris.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the formal ether sedimentation technique, parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D. This sediment is where parasitic elements are found and examined under a microscope.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss and looked jaundiced. Upon further investigation, you suspect a parasitic infection. You obtain a stool sample and operculated eggs in the feces. Further examination reveals the presence of a parasite with a complex life cycle with snail and plants as the intermediate host. Which parasite is most likely responsible for the above symptoms? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica

 

Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals.

 

Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

 

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation.

 

Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.

 

Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fasciolopsis buski: Fasciolopsis buski is an intestinal fluke, and while it also involves snails as intermediate hosts, it does not primarily target the liver. Infection typically occurs through ingestion of aquatic plants, but the symptoms and life cycle do not match those described.

 

Option C. Paragonimus westermani: Paragonimus westermani, the lung fluke, has a complex life cycle involving snails and crustaceans. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms rather than abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Eggs are typically found in sputum, not feces.

 

Option D. Clonorchis sinensis: Clonorchis sinensis, the Chinese liver fluke, also involves snails as intermediate hosts and can cause liver-related symptoms. However, the life cycle and specific hosts differ slightly from Fasciola hepatica. It primarily affects the liver and bile ducts but is more common in certain geographic regions.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Fasciola hepatica, the sheep liver fluke, is diagnosed by identifying eggs in the feces, and it has a complex life cycle involving snails and aquatic vegetation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows highest concentration in the serum? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ig-G

 

IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the serum. It plays a crucial role in the body's immune response by neutralizing pathogens, opsonizing for phagocytosis, and activating the complement system. IgG is also the only immunoglobulin that can cross the placenta, providing passive immunity to the fetus.

 

Immunoglobulins concentration in the serum are as follow -

 

Ig-G > Ig-A > Ig-M > Ig-D > Ig-E

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ig-M: Incorrect. While IgM is the first antibody to respond to an infection, it is not the most abundant in the serum.

 

Option B. Ig-A: Incorrect. IgA is present in mucosal areas and secretions, but not in the highest concentration in the serum.

 

Option C. Ig-E: Incorrect. IgE is the least abundant in the serum and is primarily involved in allergic responses.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

The Nipah virus is known to be transmitted by fruit bats, specifically the Pteropus species, which are commonly found in South Asia. The virus can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis in humans, symptoms that match the presentation in this case (fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis). The close association between fruit farming and fruit bats increases the risk of transmission, especially in South Asia where the Nipah virus is more prevalent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is known for causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It does not cause severe respiratory symptoms or encephalitis as described in this case.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. It presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically cause breathlessness or encephalitis.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Although Ebola can be associated with bats, it primarily causes hemorrhagic fever and is less associated with respiratory symptoms or encephalitis compared to Nipah virus. Also, Ebola is more commonly linked with direct human-to-human transmission or through contact with infected animals' bodily fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

questions.text: Which of the following cells is activated when there is absence or downregulation of MHC class I molecules on cell surface? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: C) NK cells

 

Explanation: 

 

NK cells are activated by the absence or downregulation of MHC class I molecules on cell surfaces ("missing self" hypothesis). When virally infected or transformed cells attempt to evade cytotoxic T cell recognition by reducing MHC class I expression, NK cells recognize this absence and become activated to kill these cells. This is mediated through inhibitory receptors on NK cells that normally bind to MHC class I - when MHC class I is missing, the inhibitory signal is lost, leading to NK cell activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Helper T cells: These CD4+ cells are activated by antigens presented via MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells, not by the absence of MHC class I.

 

Option B) Cytotoxic T cells: CD8+ T cells require the presence, not absence, of MHC class I presenting specific antigens for their activation. They are inhibited when MHC class I is downregulated.

 

Option D) B cells: These cells recognize free antigens through their B cell receptors and require help from CD4+ T cells that recognize antigens presented on MHC class II. They are not directly influenced by MHC class I levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The unique mechanism of NK cell activation through the "missing self" hypothesis and how it complements cytotoxic T cell responses in immune surveillance against virally infected or transformed cells.

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of epidemic or louse-borne typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

 

Pediculus corporis (human body louse) is the vector for the parasite, although the head louse may also transmit the disease. After the incubation period of 5 - 15 days, the disease typically starts with fever and chills. By around 4 - 5th day of fever, a characteristic rash appears, which starts on the trunk and spreads over the limbs but spares the face, palms, and soles.

 

The infection can be transmitted by

 

  • Contaminated louse feces rubbed through abrasions caused by scratching
  • Inhalation of aerosols of dried louse feces or directly through the conjunctiva

 

The disease is often severe with the fever lasting for over 2 weeks and is more fatal in patients older than 40 years of age.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia typhi causes murine (flea-borne) or endemic typhus. Rats are the reservoirs of infection and the parasite is transmitted by Xenopsylla cheopis (flea). The infection is transmitted when the flea feces is rubbed into the bite wound. The clinical features are similar to that of epidemic typhus but are milder and rarely fatal.

 

Patients can present with fever, headache, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Rickettsia akari causes rickettsial pox, which is a mild disease resembling varicella. The disease is transmitted by mites and the patients may present with fever, headache, and a vesicular rash.

 

Option D. Rickettsia conorii causes the Mediterranean spotted fever. The parasite is transmitted by ticks and the patients present with fever, headache, rash, and eschar (tache noire).

 

Educational Objective

 

Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles.
