Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureaplasma urealyticum

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall.

 

They vary in form, although most have sterols that make the cell membrane somewhat more rigid.

 

Many are able to move about through gliding, but members of the genus Spiroplasma are helical and move by twisting.

 

The best-known genus in the Mollicutes is Mycoplasma. Colonies show the typical “fried-egg” appearance.

 

Mollicutes are parasites of various animals and plants, living on or in the host’s cells. Many cause diseases in humans, attaching to cells in the respiratory or urogenital tracts, particularly species of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma. Phytoplasma and Spiroplasma are plant pathogens associated with insect vectors.

 

Ureaplasma urealyticum has the ability to hydrolyse urea. It causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Orientia tsutsugamushi: This bacterium belongs to the family Rickettsiaceae and is the causative agent of scrub typhus, which is transmitted by mites.

 

Option C. Chlamydophila pneumonia: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydophila, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Chlamydia trachomatis: This bacterium belongs to the genus Chlamydia, which is part of the Chlamydiaceae family. It causes various infections, including trachoma and sexually transmitted infections.

 

Educational Objective

 

Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma, with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: A HIV patient is presenting with cough without sputum, on examination his CD4 counts were <100 and chest x ray shown bilateral infiltration of lung, on further proceeding Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the organisms were positive for acid fast staining, what is the organism responsible for his condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium avium complex

 

Based on the clinical presentation, CD4 count, radiographic findings, and positive acid-fast staining in the bronchoalveolar lavage, the most likely organism responsible for the patient's condition is Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), which is a group of bacteria that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV/AIDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii is a fungus that commonly causes pneumonia in people with weakened immune systems, including those with HIV/AIDS. However, the cough in this case is without sputum, which is not typical of Pneumocystis pneumonia. Although PCP is common in patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL, it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus is a fungus that can cause a severe lung infection and meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not stain positive for acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with a positive acid-fast stain and is not commonly associated with lung infiltrates seen on chest X-rays in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In HIV patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL presenting with a cough without sputum, bilateral lung infiltrates on chest x-ray, and positive acid-fast staining, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most likely causative organism.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

 

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Serotype-specific tests:

 

  • Microscopic agglutination test
  • Macroscopic agglutination test

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Widal test: Incorrect, the Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever, which involves testing for antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens but does not present with the same symptom profile as described.

 

Option C. Weil Felix reaction: Incorrect, this test is historically used for diagnosing rickettsial infections, which are caused by different organisms and have different clinical features.

 

Option D. Paul Bunnell test (monospot test): Incorrect, this test is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, characterized by symptoms like fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes but not typically associated with icterus or hematuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in patients presenting with symptoms like fever, jaundice, red eyes, and hematuria, as it accurately detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira, confirming the infection.

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trombiculid mite

 

The above picture shows the life cycle of trombiculid mite.

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, an obligate intracellular Gram-negative bacterium, is the causative agent of scrub typhus, a vector-borne disease transmitted by infected chiggers (trombiculid mite larvae).

 

Host: A number of small rodents particularly wild rats of subgenus Rattus are the natural hosts for scrub typhus

 

The incubation period of scrub typhus is about 6 to 21 days

 

The infection is transmitted to man and rodents by some species of infective trombiculid mites.

 

Once, the mite is infected in nature by feeding on the body fluid of small mammals, including the rodents, they maintain the infection throughout their life stages and, as adults, pass the infection on to their eggs in a process called transovarial transmission. Similarly, the infection passes from the egg to the larva or adult in a process called transstadial transmission. In this way, chigger mite populations can autonomously maintain their infectivity over long periods of time.

 

A large number of the Orientia tsutsugamushi are present in the salivary glands of the larvae and these are injected into its host when it feeds. The bite of the mite leaves a characteristic black eschar that is useful to the doctor for making the diagnosis.

 

Human infection takes place when man accidentally picks up an infective larval mite while walking, sitting, or lying on the infested ground.

 

The adult mites have a four-stage lifecycle: egg, larva, nymph and adult.

 

The larva is the only stage (chigger) that can transmit the disease to humans and other vertebrates, since the other life stages (nymph and adult) do not feed on vertebrate animals. Both the nymph and the adult are free-living in the soil.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hard tick: Hard ticks, such as Ixodes species, are vectors for diseases like Lyme disease and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Option B. Soft tick: Soft ticks, like Ornithodoros species, are vectors for diseases such as tick-borne relapsing fever, but are not depicted in the life cycle in the image.

 

Option D. Louse: Lice are vectors for diseases like epidemic typhus, caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, and are not involved in the life cycle shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective

 

The trombiculid mite, particularly its larval stage (chigger), is the vector for scrub typhus, transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans and rodents through its bite, which leaves a characteristic black eschar.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The image shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

The infective form of strongyloides is the filariform larva. Infection occurs through penetration of the skin by larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This is another helminth with a similar skin-penetrating infection method, but its life cycle is characterized by direct development into adult worms in the intestine after migration, without a free-living phase.

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: This helminth has a different life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which then hatch in the intestine, and larvae migrate through the liver and lungs before maturing in the intestine.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis: Known as pinworm, this helminth has a life cycle involving the ingestion of eggs, which hatch in the intestine, and the adult worms live in the colon and rectum.

 

Educational Objective:


Strongyloides stercoralis infects through skin penetration by filariform larvae from contaminated soil.

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cefotetan

 

Burkholderia cepacia complex is known for its intrinsic resistance to various antimicrobial agents, including cefotetan.

 

B. Cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to:

 

  • Aminoglycosides
  • Polymixin
  • First and second-generation cephalosporins
  • Carboxypenicillins

 

B. Cepacia can cause severe necrotizing pneumonia in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. It can lead to fatal septicemia in patients with cystic fibrosis.

 

Antimicrobial agents that are effective against B. cepacia complex include:

 

  • Meropenem
  • Ceftazidime
  • Piperacillin
  • Temocillin
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ceftazidime: Incorrect because ceftazidime is actually among the antimicrobials that are effective against B. cepacia complex, suggesting it can bypass the bacterium’s resistance mechanisms.

 

Option B. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Incorrect, as this combination is also effective against B. cepacia, demonstrating its capability to treat infections caused by this pathogen.

 

Option C. Temocillin: Incorrect, as temocillin is listed as effective against B. cepacia complex, indicating its efficacy in combating this resistant bacterium.

 

Educational Objective

 

Burkholderia cepacia exhibits resistance to several antibiotic classes, including second-generation cephalosporins like cefotetan.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia

 

Explanation:

 

Orientia, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is transmitted by chigger mites, not by the tick shown in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Babesia: Transmitted by ticks

 

Option C. Ehrlichia: Also transmitted by ticks

 

Option D. Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever : Also transmitted by ticks

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orientia tsutsugamushi, responsible for scrub typhus, is not transmitted by ticks but by chigger mites, distinguishing it from other tick-borne infections like Babesia and Ehrlichia.

questions.text: Most common agent responsible for UTI in children is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E. coli

 

Explanation:

 

E. coli is the most frequent causative agent of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children. It accounts for 80-85% of all UTIs due to its ability to adhere to the uroepithelium via specific adhesins and pili, which facilitate infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Klebsiella: While Klebsiella can cause UTIs, it is less common compared to E. coli.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas is more commonly associated with complicated UTIs, especially in hospitalized or catheterized patients, rather than being the primary agent in children.

 

Option D. Streptococcus: Streptococcus species are not a common cause of UTIs in children.

 

Educational objective:

 

E. coli is the predominant pathogen responsible for urinary tract infections in children.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

questions.text: Diphtheria toxin MOA is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ADP ribosylation of EF2 Inhibiting protein synthesis

 

Diphtheria toxin exerts its toxic effects by inhibiting protein synthesis in the host cell. The mechanism involves the ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2), which is a critical component in the protein synthesis machinery of the cell. By modifying EF-2, diphtheria toxin prevents the translocation step in protein elongation, effectively halting protein production. This leads to cell death and contributes to the pathogenic effects of the infection.

 

Mnemonic "Delhi Public Secondary School" (DPSS): The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acting on 60s Ribosome: This is incorrect because diphtheria toxin specifically targets elongation factor 2 (EF-2) rather than the ribosome directly. It interferes with protein synthesis by modifying EF-2, not by acting on the ribosome.

 

Option B. Increasing cAMP: This option is incorrect as it describes the mechanism of action of other bacterial toxins like those produced by Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). These toxins increase the intracellular levels of cAMP by activating adenyl cyclase, which is not the mechanism for diphtheria toxin.

 

Option C. Decreasing cGMP: This is incorrect. The mechanism involving the decrease of cGMP is not relevant to diphtheria toxin. Diphtheria toxin's action is specific to inhibiting protein synthesis through the ADP ribosylation of EF-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MOA

 

The four toxins that inhibit protein synthesis by modifying EF-2: Diphtheria toxin, Pseudomonas toxin, Shiga toxin, and Shiga-like toxin. (Mnemonic: Delhi Public Secondary School /DPSS)

 

The four toxin act by increasing cAMP: Bacillus anthracis, Vibrio cholerae, Bordetella pertussis, and enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). (Mnemonic: Be Very Efficient Boy/BVEB)

questions.text: A 11-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, toxic appearance, and severe respiratory distress following mild upper respiratory symptoms. Chest X-ray shows subglottic narrowing with irregular tracheal margins and membrane-like opacities. Which organism is the most likely cause? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans: B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Explanation: 

 

The presentation describes bacterial tracheitis, typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus. This condition often follows a viral upper respiratory infection and is characterized by high-grade fever, toxic appearance, and severe respiratory distress. The X-ray shows subglottic narrowing with irregular tracheal margins and membrane-like opacities, distinguishing it from the smooth "steeple sign" of viral croup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Parainfluenza virus: Causes viral croup with barking cough and stridor but presents with low-grade fever and less toxicity. X-ray shows classic smooth "steeple sign."

 

Option C) Respiratory syncytial virus: Typically causes bronchiolitis in younger children with wheezing and crackles. X-ray shows hyperinflation and patchy infiltrates.

 

Option D) Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Usually causes walking pneumonia with gradual onset, dry cough, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on X-ray.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To differentiate bacterial tracheitis from viral croup and other respiratory infections based on clinical presentation and radiological findings, emphasizing the more severe nature and different causative organism of bacterial tracheitis compared to viral respiratory infections.

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

 

  • The provided clinical scenario presents a patient with symptoms of anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an accompanying image displaying hydrops fetalis.
  • These manifestations collectively suggest a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum, commonly known as Fifth disease, which is caused by parvovirus B19.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

 

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

 

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

 

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Treponema pallidum (Syphilis) in pregnancy leads to subsequent pregnancy loss.

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) by trans placental spread causes fetal damage at all gestational ages. Features are periventricular calcifications, microcephaly, hearing loss, hydrops fetalis.

 

Option D. Toxoplasma gondii intracerebral calcifications, hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Parvovirus B19 is responsible for severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and other serious complications in fetuses.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

 

  • Marrack proposed the lattice hypothesis → Multivalent antigens combine with Bivalent antibodies
  • Lattice is formed only when antigen and antibodies are in proportion.
  • If antigen or antibodies ,any of them is in excess - there is no lattice formation
  • The absence of a positive test result in the initial two tubes can be attributed to the prozone phenomenon.
  • In this scenario, there is an excess of antibodies in comparison to antigens, which results in a lack of robust or noticeable precipitation.

 

Zone phenomenon:

 

  1. Prozone = Ab excess = Absent
  2. Zone of equivalence = Proper proportion = Peak
  3. Post zone = Ag excess = Absent

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Incorrect antigen: If the antigen were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option B. Incorrect antibody: If the antibody were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option D. Antigen excess: Antigen excess would cause a postzone phenomenon, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospira

 

The organisms in the image are leptospira.

 

In spirochetes, the presence of two axial filaments (periplasmic flagella) with polar insertions are located in periplasmic space called as endoflagella, which are responsible for the characteristic corkscrew motion of these bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species are comma-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, commonly known for causing cholera (Vibrio cholerae).

 

Option C. Helicobacter: Helicobacter pylori are spiral-shaped bacteria known for causing stomach ulcers and are Gram-negative.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Salmonella species are rod-shaped, Gram-negative bacteria, known for causing foodborne illnesses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leptospira is identified by its spiral morphology with axial filaments (endoflagella) and is a type of spirochete, along with Treponema and Borrelia.

 

Endoflagella are seen in:

 

  • Treponema
  • Borrelia
  • Leptospira

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a high fever, weight loss, and a localized abscess on his leg. He has recently returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. Ultrasound of the leg reveals a complex abscess with possible involvement of the underlying bone. A sample of the abscess fluid is sent for culture. Which organism is most commonly associated with abscess formation in this clinical setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Burkholderia pseudomallei

 

Option B:

 

Burkholderia pseudomallei is the causative agent of melioidosis, which is endemic in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. It is a gram-negative bacillus found in soil and water and can infect humans through inoculation from a contaminated source. Melioidosis often presents with abscess formation and can involve multiple organs, including the skin and bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Burkholderia mallei: Causes glanders, which is primarily a disease of animals such as horses, and human infections are rare.

 

Option C. Burkholderia cepacia: Mainly associated with respiratory infections in patients with cystic fibrosis, not typically known for causing abscesses in travelers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia pseudomallei as the causative organism of melioidosis, commonly presenting with abscesses and commonly contracted in Southeast Asia.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p342, 2/e p355, Ananthanarayan 9/e p317, 18, 10/e p323-324
